case_name: Civil Appeal No. 514 of 1970 and connected appeals

facts.text: These appeals arise out of the judgment of the High Court of Mysore dismissing a batch of writ petitions filed by a number of dealers in the State of Mysore questioning the levy of sales tax under the Central Sales Tax Act on certain inter-State sales.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by ALAGIRISWAMI, J.-These appeals arise out of the judgment of the High Court of Mysore dismissing a batch of writ petitions filed by a number of dealers in the State of Mysore  number Karnataka  questioning the levy of sales tax under the Central Sales Tax Act on certain interState sales.

facts.text: The goods dealt with were all declared goods and under the Mysore Sales Tax Act they were taxable at the point of purchase at a single point.

anchor.surface_text: The goods dealt with were all declared goods and under the Mysore Sales Tax Act they were taxable at the point of purchase at a single point. The assessment periods are prior to 10th November, 1964.

facts.text: The assessment periods are prior to 10th November, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The assessment periods are prior to 10th November, 1964. The importance of this date will become clear when we proceed to deal with the matter subsequently.

facts.text: The assessing authorities assessed all these transactions of inter-State sales to tax.

anchor.surface_text: The assessing authorities assessed all these transactions of inter-State sales to tax. This Court delivered its judgment in what is known as Yaddalams Case  16 STC 231  holding that where a certain transaction was

facts.text: This Court delivered its judgment in what is known as Yaddalams Case 16 STC 231 holding that where a certain transaction was liable to sales tax if it were an intra-state sale under the Sales Tax Law of the appropriate State, it would be liable to sales tax if it were an inter-State sale.

anchor.surface_text: This Court delivered its judgment in what is known as Yaddalams Case  16 STC 231  holding that where a certain transaction was number liable to sales tax if it were an intra-state sale under the Sales Tax Law of the appropriate State, it would number be liable to sales tax if it were an inter-State sale.

facts.text: Following this decision the assessment orders were rectified giving effect to the judgment.

anchor.surface_text: Following this decision the assessment orders were rectified giving effect to the judgment. To set aside the effect of this decision sub-S  1A  was inserted in section 6 and a companysequential amendment was made in sub-s.  2A  of section 8 of the Central Sales Tax Act.

facts.text: sub-S 1A was inserted in section 6 and a consequential amendment was made in sub-s. 2A of section 8 of the Central Sales Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: To set aside the effect of this decision sub-S  1A  was inserted in section 6 and a companysequential amendment was made in sub-s.  2A  of section 8 of the Central Sales Tax Act. After this the assessing authorities again rectified the assessment orders and brought to tax the inter-State sales.

facts.text: After this the assessing authorities again rectified the assessment orders and brought to tax the inter-State sales.

anchor.surface_text: After this the assessing authorities again rectified the assessment orders and brought to tax the inter-State sales. Before this Court the validity of section 8 2  a  as well as section 6  IA  of the Central Sales Tax Act read with section 10 of the Central Salex Tax  Amendment  Act, 1969 is questioned.

facts.text: Before this Court the validity of section 8(2)(a) as well as section 6(1A) of the Central Sales Tax Act read with section 10 of the Central Sales Tax Amendment Act, 1969 is questioned.

anchor.surface_text: Before this Court the validity of section 8 2  a  as well as section 6  IA  of the Central Sales Tax Act read with section 10 of the Central Salex Tax  Amendment  Act, 1969 is questioned. In the alternative it is argued that even after the amendment these transactions are number liable to sales tax.

facts.text: The rectification orders are impugned on the ground that there was no mistake apparent on the face of the record to justify the rectification under Rule 38 of the Mysore Sales Tax Rules.

anchor.surface_text: The rectification orders are also impugned on the ground 1. that there was numbermistake apparent on the face of the record to ,justify the rectification under Rule 38 of the Mysore Sales Tax Rules, and 2. that in any case such rectification is beyond the permitted period.

arguments.claim: Section 8(2)(a) of the Central Sales Tax Act is unconstitutional due to excessive delegation of legislative power, analogous to challenge against section 8(2)(b)

anchor.surface_text: The first contention regarding the unconstitutionality of section 8 2   a  is sought to be based on the decision of this Court in G. Rayon Silk Mfg.  Wvg.  Co. Ltd. v. Asst. Commr.  1  dealing with the constitutionality of S. 8 2  b . We consider that far from supporting the appellants that decision actually is against the contention put forward on behalf of the appellants.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ment number being a registered dealer, a certificate in the prescribed form duly filled and signed by a duly authorised officer of the Government. in

arguments.court_reasoning: G. Rayon Silk upheld similar provision in s.8(2)(b); clear legislative policy to prevent evasion by adopting higher state rates.

arguments.claim: No excessive delegation in s.8(2)(a) as Parliament laid down clear policy to prevent tax evasion by linking to state rates

anchor.surface_text: Section 8 2  b  of the Act has plainly been enacted with a view to prevent evasion of the payment of the Central sales tax. The Act prescribes a low rate of tax of 3 per cent in the case of inter-State sales only if the goods are sold to the Government or to a registered dealer other than the Government.

arguments.claim: Tax rate under s.8(2)(a) is the rate prevalent at the time of enactment of the section, not subsequent variations

anchor.surface_text: it is next contended that as section 8 2  a  states that the tax payable shall be calculated at the rate applicable to the sale or purchase of such goods inside the appropriate State it is the rate that was prevalent when section 8 2  a  was enacted that would be applicable and not any subsequent variation in this rate of tax.

arguments.court_reasoning: Rate applicable at relevant time of sale to avoid discrimination and align with scheme of adopting state machinery and rates.

arguments.claim: Rate under s.8(2)(a) is applicable at the relevant point of time, consistent with Act's scheme to avoid discrimination between intra and inter-state sales

anchor.surface_text: All that is necessary now to add is that the rate applicable merely means the rate applicable at the relevant point of time and not the rate applicable when section 8 2  a  was enacted. The whole scheme of the Central Sales Tax Act is to adopt the machinery of the law relating to Sales Tax Acts of the various States

arguments.claim: Section 10 exemption does not violate Art 14; Legislature may grant concession to one set without extending to others similarly situated prior

anchor.surface_text: A concession is not a matter of right. anchor.surface_text: Clearly when it said that the effect of the Central Sales Tax Amendment Act, 1969 is to supersede the judgment of this Court in Yaddalams case the Sales Tax Authorities were undoubtedly entitled to rectify their earlier rectification order which was made consequent on the decision in Yaddalams case.

holdings.text: Section 8(2)(a) of the Central Sales Tax Act is constitutionally valid and the contention of excessive delegation of legislative power is not well-founded.

anchor.surface_text: companystitutionality of S. 8 2  b . We companysider that far from supporting the appellants that decision actually is against the companytention put forward on behalf of the appellants. It is only necessary to Set out what this Court said in that decision. It is hardly necessary to add any thing more. In that case the majority while upholding the validity of section 8 2  b  observed It has been argued on behalf of the appellants that the fixation of rate of tax is a legislative function and as the Parliament has. under section 8 2  b  of the Act, number fixed the rate of Central sales tax but has adopted the rate applicable to the sale or purchase of goods inside the appropriate State in case such rate exceeds 10 per cent, the parliament has abdicated its legislative function. The above provision is companysequently stated to be companystitutionally invalid because of excessive delegation of legislative power. This companytention, in our opinion, is number well- founded.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Relies on precedent in G. Rayon Silk upholding similar provision in s.8(2)(b); Parliament laid clear policy to prevent tax evasion by adopting state rates where higher.

holdings.text: The rate applicable under section 8(2)(a) is the rate at the relevant point of time of the sale, not the rate at the time of enactment.

anchor.surface_text: All that is necessary now to add is that the rate applicable merely means the rate applicable at the relevant point of time and not the rate applicable when section 8 2  a  was enacted. The whole scheme of the Central Sales Tax Act is to adopt the machinery of the law relating to Sales Tax Acts of the various States

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of Act adopts state machinery and rates at relevant time to avoid discrimination between intra-state and inter-state sales and ensure convenience.

holdings.text: Sub-section (1A) of section 6 does not violate Article 14 in view of section 10 of the Central Sales Tax Amendment Act, 1969.

anchor.surface_text: A concession is not a matter of right. Where the Legislature taking into consideration the hardships caused to a certain set of taxpayers gives them a certain concession it does not mean that action is bad as another set of tax-payers similarly situated may not have been given a similar concession.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislature can grant concession to one group without extending to others; no right to concession; court cannot legislate similar relief for prior periods.

holdings.text: Sub-section (2A) of section 8 does not impliedly repeal sub-section (1A) of section 6; both provisions operate harmoniously.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this contention. Firstly, such an intention cannot be imputed to Parliament which enacted both the provisions at the same time. Both the provisions should, therefore be so read as not to nullify the effect of the one or the other

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provisions enacted simultaneously; read harmoniously; s.8(2A) exempts only if wholly exempt under state law, not single-point taxation; s.6(1A) makes liable if intra-state liable at single point.

holdings.text: There was a mistake apparent on the face of the record justifying rectification of the assessment orders under Rule 38 of the Mysore Sales Tax Rules.

anchor.surface_text: Clearly when it said that the effect of the Central Sales Tax Amendment Act, 1969 is to supersede the judgment of this Court in Yaddalams case the Sales Tax Authorities were undoubtedly entitled to rectify their earlier rectification order which was made consequent on the decision in Yaddalams case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Amendment Act 1969 supersedes Yaddalam's case; post-Joseph case, prior non-taxation was clear error; authorities entitled to rectify.

holdings.text: The rectification orders were not beyond the permitted period.

anchor.surface_text: Clearly when it said that the effect of the Central Sales Tax Amendment Act, 1969 is to supersede the judgment of this Court in Yaddalams case the Sales Tax Authorities were undoubtedly entitled to rectify their earlier rectification order which was made consequent on the decision in Yaddalams case. After the Central Sales Tax Amendment Act. 1969 and the decision of this Courting Josephs case there was no question about the error not being apparent on the face of the record. This attack on the rectification order, therefore, fails.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rectification upheld overall as valid post-amendment; no separate bar on time mentioned, implicitly within period.

We companysider that far from supporting the appellants that decision actually is against the companytention put forward on behalf of the appellants. It is only necessary to Set out what this Court said in that decision. It is hardly necessary to add any thing more. In that case the majority while upholding the validity of section 8 2  b  observed It has been argued on behalf of the appellants that the fixation of rate of tax is a legislative function and as the Parliament has. under section 8 2  b  of the Act, number fixed the rate of Central sales tax but has adopted the rate applicable to the sale or purchase of goods inside the appropriate State in case such rate exceeds 10 per cent, the parliament has abdicated its legislative function. The above provision is companysequently stated to be companystitutionally invalid because of excessive delegation of legislative power. This companytention, in our opinion, is number well- founded.
This attack on the rectification order, therefore. fails.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this contention. Firstly, such an intention cannot be imputed to Parliament which enacted both the provisions at the same time. Both the provisions should, therefore be so read as not to nullify the effect of the one or the other
This attack on the rectification order, therefore. fails.

Clearly when it said that the effect of the Central Sales Tax Amendment Act, 1969 is to supersede the judgment of this Court in Yaddalams case the Sales Tax Authorities were undoubtedly entitled to rectify their earlier rectification order which was made consequent on the decision in Yaddalams case.
This attack on the rectification order, therefore. fails.

Clearly when it said that the effect of the Central Sales Tax Amendment Act, 1969 is to supersede the judgment of this Court in Yaddalams case the Sales Tax Authorities were undoubtedly entitled to rectify their earlier rectification order which was made consequent on the decision in Yaddalams case. After the Central Sales Tax Amendment Act. 1969 and the decision of this Courting Josephs case there was no question about the error not being apparent on the face of the record. This attack on the rectification order, therefore, fails.
